definition.en: Facial redness can be temporary or chronic, caused by dilated blood vessels, inflammation, sensitive skin, or skin conditions like rosacea. It often appears on cheeks, nose, chin, and forehead.

prevention: Pat skin dry, don't rub vigorously
Avoid heavy exercise in hot weather

mild.description: Occasional flushing, temporary redness after triggers

moderate.description: Persistent redness, visible blood vessels, frequent flushing

severe.description: Chronic redness, multiple visible blood vessels (spider veins), rosacea
options: Excel V laser for vascular lesions

whenToSeeDermatologist: Persistent redness lasting more than 2 weeks
Redness accompanied by pustules or papules (rosacea suspected)
Visible spider veins or broken capillaries
Redness causing significant discomfort or burning
Suspect rosacea or other skin condition
Redness significantly affects quality of life

statistics.women: Women 3x more likely than men to have rosacea

myths.myth: Redness is just cosmetic and harmless
myths.fact: Chronic redness can be a sign of rosacea or other conditions that worsen over time without treatment.

myths.myth: Redness means you're allergic to products
myths.fact: While allergies can cause redness, chronic redness is often due to rosacea, sensitivity, or broken capillaries - not allergies.

myths.myth: Rosacea is caused by poor hygiene
myths.fact: Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory condition, not related to cleanliness. Over-cleansing can actually worsen it.
Laser treatments (V-beam, IPL) are highly effective at eliminating broken capillaries.

morning: Lukewarm water rinse (or gentle cream cleanser)
evening: Occlusive layer (squalane or vaseline) if very dry

avoid: Vitamin C (L-ascorbic acid) if very sensitive

vbeam.description: Pulsed dye laser - gold standard for redness

ipl.description: Intense Pulsed Light - broad spectrum light
ipl.bestFor: General redness, sun damage, multiple concerns
